newsitem.title: MEXICO: Officials prepare Clinton's visit to Mexico May 5-7.
newsitem.headline: Officials prepare Clinton's visit to Mexico May 5-7.

text.p: U.S. officials on Sunday said they were putting the final touches to a visit President Bill Clinton will make to Mexico May 5-7, the first of a series he plans to make to Latin America.

Thomas "Mack" McLarty, special adviser to Clinton, was scheduled to meet Mexican Foreign Minister Jose Angel Gurria and other Mexican officials on Sunday and Monday to finalize details of the Clinton visit.
Clinton will meet Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo and join him for a news conference. There are also plans for him to give a speech, White House officials said earlier.
McLarty told reporters Mexico and the United States needed to work together to fight drug trafficking.
"Our progress as sovereign nations is being threatened today by a variety of dark and evil forces including narcotics corruption, crime and international terrorism," he said.
The United States certified Mexico as a U.S. ally in the war against illegal drugs in February despite protests from some members of Congress that Mexico's record was inadequate.
Clinton's anti-drug czar, retired Gen. Barry McCaffrey, was in Mexico City on Wednesday for talks on drug policy, a key issue on Clinton's agenda during his Mexican visit.
The week-long trip will also take Clinton to Costa Rica to attend a Central American summit and then to Barbados for a Caribbean summit.
Clinton's visit had been planned for this month but was delayed after he tore a knee tendon at the Florida home of golfer Greg Norman on March 14 and underwent surgery.
Clinton will travel to at least seven countries on three trips to the Caribbean and Latin America over the next year, McLarty said.
"We believe that it is appropriate and highly symbolic that Mexico be the first stop on President Clinton's hemispheric journey," McLarty said.
